Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Interdisciplinary Study of Mineral-Biomolecule Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The inanimate world of minerals and the dynamic domains of life might at first glance seem unrelated. Yet interactions between mineral surfaces and life's varied biomolecules are ubiquitous in our environment, and are crucial to an extraordinarily broad range of scientific and technological topics. Mineral-molecule interactions play key roles in microbial ecology, environmental monitoring, corrosion and weathering, synthesis and purification of pharmaceuticals, planetary life detection, nanofabrication, and the development of artificial replacements for teeth and bones. These interactions are also key to a host of essential everyday products, including adhesives, paints, lubricants, dyes, solvents and cleaners. Geochemists pay special attention to reactions that occur between mineral surfaces and aqueous molecular species - interactions central to the breakdown of rocks and subsequent soil formation, hydrothermal ore deposition, pH buffering of lakes and oceans, biomineralization and biofilm formation, uptake and release of chemicals that affect water quality, and many other natural processes. Mineral-molecule interactions are also relevant to many models of the origins of life, in such varied roles as the selection, concentration, protection and assembly of biomolecules.
In this project investigators employ a diverse arsenal of experimental and theoretical techniques to understand atomic-scale phenomena associated with mineral-molecule interfaces. They will characterize surfaces of such important minerals as rutile (TiO2 - the surface coating of titanium bone replacement and an important constituent of paints), calcite (the commonest biomineral), and apatite (the most important mineral in teeth and bones). They will investigate the interactions of these and other minerals with key biomolecules, including amino acids (the building blocks of proteins), molecular components of the genetic molecules DNA and RNA, and common biological sugars. Building on recent advances, and harnessing resources of the Carnegie Institution, Johns Hopkins University, the University of Delaware, Pennsylvania State University, Northwestern University, Argonne National Laboratory and other institutions, this proposed collaborative interdisciplinary research program will continue to document in detail conditions under which specific molecules adsorb to specific mineral surfaces, while revealing molecular-scale aspects of those interactions. Researchers will investigate the nature and extent of competitive and cooperative adsorption of small biomolecules, including amino acids and pentose sugars. They will also expand the scope to study possible roles of rock-forming mineral surfaces in life's origins, notably in the selection and stabilization of biomolecules, as well as polymerization reactions. The ultimate objective of this project is thus to develop general principles governing the adsorption of organic species on mineral surfaces - principles that will have broad application to science and industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For many decades theories about the origin of life have speculated on the possible role of minerals on the early Earth and what effect minerals had on the evolution of the molecules important for biology. However, remarkably little was known even about how the molecules attach to minerals. We studied how the biologically important building blocks of proteins and DNA/RNA interact with minerals. such as amino acids and nuclesides. We particularly wanted to focus on exactly how these molecules attach to the surfaces of minerals and how these attachments might change as a function of a changing environment.

In order to do this we studied several different amino acids and mineral surfaces by measuring the amount of each molecule attached to the surfaces as functions of aqueous solution pH, salt concentration, and molecule loading. These experimental data were used to calibrate a theoretical model of the attachment process in order to be able to make predictions of the nature of the attachment process.

Our theoretical predictions were tested using state of the art laboratory techniques including surface infrared and Raman spectroscopy. Excellent agreement was found between the predicted changes of the attached species and the spectroscopic evidence. We also tested our theoretical modeling results using electron microscopy to measure the number of attachment sites on the mineral rutile (titanium dioxide).

The next phase of our study was to go to higher temperatures and investigate the stability of amino acids in hot water as a function of the redox state. We found that dissolved H2 helped to stabilize the amino acid glutamate at 160 to 250 °C which provides support for the long-standing hydrothermal theory of the origin of life.

Overall, our results strongly support the theory that minerals could have concentrated biomolecules on their surfaces and that these biomolecules might have been able to survive high temperature water. These results are a first step in helping to decipher the emergence and selection of the first biomolecules in the origin of life.
